perturbation.original_text: Each Sponsor represents and warrants to each other Party that such Sponsor is bound by and has complied with,  and agrees that such Sponsor shall continue to be bound by and comply with, the Equity Commitment Letter and that each other Sponsor (other  than any Defaulting Sponsor) shall be entitled to enforce, or direct the enforcement of, such Equity Commitment Letter in accordance with this  Agreement if and only if the Sponsors (other than any Defaulting Sponsor) have determined by unanimous written consent that the conditions of  the Offer have been satisfied or to waive all such conditions remaining unsatisfied. No Party shall attempt to enforce any Equity Commitment  Letter until the conditions set forth in this Section have been satisfied. Purchaser shall have no right to enforce any Equity Commitment Letter  unless and until directed to do so by the unanimous written consent of the Sponsors (other than any Defaulting Sponsor).
perturbation.changed_text: Each Investor represents and warrants to each other Party that such Investor is bound by and has complied with,  and agrees that such Investor shall continue to be bound by and comply with, the Equity Commitment Letter and that each other Sponsor (other  than any Defaulting Funder) shall be entitled to enforce, or direct the enforcement of, such Equity Commitment Letter in accordance with this  Agreement if and only if the Investors (other than any Defaulting Funder) have determined by unanimous written consent that the conditions of  the Offer have been satisfied or to waive all such conditions remaining unsatisfied. No Party shall attempt to enforce any Equity Commitment  Letter until the conditions set forth in this Section have been satisfied. Purchaser shall have no right to enforce any Equity Commitment Letter  unless and until directed to do so by the unanimous written consent of the Sponsors (other than any Defaulting Sponsor).
perturbation.explanation: The terms 'Sponsor' has been replaced with 'Investor' in the first sentence and 'Funder' in the second. These terms are used interchangeably without a clear definition, potentially creating confusion regarding who is bound by the warranties. It's uncertain whether 'Investor' and 'Funder' have the same obligations or whether the obligations can be enforced in the same way. This could cause disputes during enforcement, as these terms are not defined.

perturbation.original_text: Each Sponsor that has complied with the Equity Commitment Letter and this Agreement  ("Participating Sponsor") may terminate the participation in the Offer of any Sponsor that has not satisfied the funding requirements contemplated by the Equity Commitment Letter or otherwise failed to comply with the Equity Commitment Letter and this Agreement ("Defaulting  Sponsor"); provided, however, that such termination shall not affect any right of any Participating Sponsor as against such Defaulting Sponsor  with respect to such failure to fund or any such other non-compliance.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Funder that has complied with the Equity Commitment Letter and this Agreement  ("Participating Sponsor") may terminate the participation in the Offer of any Sponsor that has not satisfied the funding requirements contemplated by the Equity Commitment Letter or otherwise failed to comply with the Equity Commitment Letter and this Agreement ("Non-Compliant Funder"); provided, however, that such termination shall not affect any right of any Participating Sponsor as against such Defaulting Sponsor  with respect to such failure to fund or any such other non-compliance.
perturbation.explanation: The terms 'Sponsor' has been replaced with 'Funder' at the start of the sentence. Also, 'Defaulting Sponsor' has been replaced with 'Non-Compliant Funder'. These changes create confusion regarding which entities the 'Participating Sponsor' can terminate. It becomes unclear whether a Funder and Sponsor are subject to the same requirements. This introduces uncertainty in termination rights and obligations.

perturbation.original_text: To the fullest extent permitted by law, each Sponsor shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless each other Sponsor  and any of its affiliates or any direct or indirect partner, member, shareholder, employee, director, officer or agent of such Sponsor or any of its  affiliates from and against any and all losses, liabilities, damages, claims, judgments, awards, settlements, demands, offsets, and expenses  (including interest, penalties, court costs, arbitration costs and fees, witness fees and reasonable fees and expenses of outside attorneys,  investigators, expert witnesses, accountants and other professionals) arising out of or relating to any material breach or inaccuracy of the  representations, warranties or covenants of such Sponsor contained herein.
perturbation.changed_text: To the fullest extent permitted by law, each Investor shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless each other Sponsor and any of its affiliates or any direct or indirect partner, member, shareholder, employee, director, officer or agent of such Sponsor or any of its affiliates from and against any and all losses, liabilities, damages, claims, judgments, awards, settlements, demands, offsets, and expenses  (including interest, penalties, court costs, arbitration costs and fees, witness fees and reasonable fees and expenses of outside attorneys, investigators, expert witnesses, accountants and other professionals) arising out of or relating to any material breach or inaccuracy of the representations, warranties or covenants of such Sponsor contained herein.
perturbation.explanation: The term 'Sponsor' has been replaced with 'Investor' at the start of the sentence. This change creates ambiguity as to who is responsible for indemnification. If 'Sponsor' and 'Investor' are not the same entity, the obligation to indemnify becomes unclear. The phrase "representations, warranties or covenants of such Sponsor contained herein" could be interpreted as limiting indemnification to only breaches by the entity still explicitly called a Sponsor, excluding 'Investor', creating an enforcement conflict. This can lead to significant disputes regarding which party is responsible for covering losses.
